en: The deceased was a Fulbright-Hays Fellow, senior I.U.C. Fellow and associate member of St. Anthony's College, Oxford (1974).
pcm: Di deceased be Fulbright-Hays Fellow, senior I.U.C. Fellow and associate member of St. Anthony's College, Oxford (1974).

en: He goes into history as the first Vice-Chancellor of Bayero University, Kano.
pcm: He enter history as di first Vice-Chancelor for Bayero University, for Kano.

en: In his career as a public servant, the prominent scholar of worldwide fame served on the Adebo and Udoji National Wage Reviews and the Constitution Drafting Committee of 1976, he was also a member of the sub-committee on Citizenship Rights, Fundamental Rights, Political Parties and Electoral System under the chairmanship of Alhaji Aminu Kano.
pcm: For im career as public servant, di scholar wey dey prominent and get fame worldwide be serve for di  Adebo and Udoji National Wage Reviews and committee wey dratf Constitution of 1976, he also be member of di sub-committee on top citizenship right,  fundamental right, Political Parties and Electoral System wey Alhaji Aminu Kano be Chairman for.

en: He was a member of the National Constitutional Conference (1994\1995) and the Vision 2010 Committee (1997).
pcm: E be member of di National Constitutional Conference (1994\1995) and di Committee for vision 2010 (1997).

en: In 1984, during the military regime of Major General Muhammadu Buhari, he was appointed Minister of Commerce and Industries by the Federal Government.
pcm: For 1984, when Major General Muhammadu Buhari be dey do military regime, Federal goment appoint am as Minister for Commerce and Industries.

en: A business executive, the late Tukur chaired the activities of Fukarabe Industries Limited, Kaduna, and fulfilled the obligations of many corporate directorships.
pcm: A business executive, late Tukur be chair for di activities of Fukarabe Industries Limited, Kaduna, and e fulfill di obligation of plenty corporate dictatorship dem.

en: He was a Coordinator of Policy Analysis Limited and authored and co-authored many books, of which the most prominent is: Leadership and Governance in Nigeria:
pcm: Leadership and Governance in Nigeria: He be Coordinator for Policy Analysis Limited and write and join pipo to write plenty book dem, wey di one wey prominent pass na:

en: The Relevance of Values, published in 1999.
pcm: Di Relevance of Values, wey dem publish for 1999.

en: He is survived by three wives, nine children and many distinguished brothers, including the prominent global industrialist and world-renowned business mogul, Alhaji Bamanga Tukur, former Governor of the defunct Gongola State, one time Minister of Industries and ex-chairman of the People's Democratic Party (PDP) and Late Engr Hamman Tukur a former Director-General Federal Ministry of Petroleum Resources and Pioneer Chairman, Revenue Mobilization and Fiscal Commission.
pcm: Na three wives dem survive am, nine children and plenty broda dem wey dey distinguished, wey include di prominent global industrialist and business mogul wey dem worldwide Alhaji Bamanga Tukur, wey be former Governor for inside Gongola State wey no dey again, one time Minister of Industries and  past chairman for di People's Democratic Party (PDP) and Late Engr Hamman Tukur former Director-General for Federal Ministry of Petroleum Resources and di first Chairman, Revenue Mobilization and Fiscal Commission.

en: We commiserate with Nigerians on the demise of this courageous academic, who, contrary to being also a match-maker, had a  more distinguished career in the service to the nation.
pcm: We dey commiserate with Nigeria pipo on top di quench of dis courageous academic, who apart from say na match-maker, be get more distinguished career for service give di nation.

en: Nigeria would surely miss the statesmanship of the Adamawa born Dr Mahmud Tukur, an enigma during his lifetime, who displayed genuine magnanimity and moral courage, and who always put national interest above ethnic or group interests.
pcm: Nigeria go surely miss di statesmanship of Dr Mahmud wey dem born for inside Adamawa, na enigma durin im lifetime, he display genuine magnanimity and moral courage, and e always dey put interest of nation above di one of ethnic or group.

en: Reputed for his uncompromising adherence to due process, he was indeed a bridge builder, ever ready to deploy his wisdom and knowledge garnered over the years for the good of his country.
pcm: Im reputation na say e dey follow due process, im na indeed bridge builder, e dey always readi to use im wisdon plus knowledge wey im don gain over di years for di good of im kontri.

en: Dr Tukur was a man of peace and unquestionable diligence and professionalism whose death is a great loss to Nigeria.
pcm: Dr Tukur be man of peace and im deligence and professionalismno dey questionable wey im death na great loss for Nigeria.

en: He lived an impactful life and contributed immensely to Nigeria and has etched his name on a platter of gold in the country's history.
pcm: He be live life wey get impact and contribute plenty to Nigeria and e don put im name for platter of gold for inside di history of di kontri.

en: We all have a collective duty to keep alive his service patriotic duty for a peaceful and secured country.
pcm: All of us must to keep im service patriotic duty for peaceful and secure kontri.

en: The federal government should immortalise him by naming any of any educative or renaming the Institute of Administration ABU Zaria in his remembrance.
pcm: Make di federal goment immortalise am as per make dem name anything wey dey follow education or di Institute of Administration ABU Zaria as im remebrance.

en: Nigeria has indeed lost a rare gem, patriotic Nigerian par excellence, an academic extraordinaire and great author, who had served this nation meritoriously, a man of strong character and conviction who led one of the most impactful lives anyone would have wished to live, going by his well-defined roles in the growth of humanity and his untiring commitment to nation-building.
pcm: Indeed Nigeria don loss rare gem, na patriotic Nigerian par excellence, na academic extraordinaire and na great author, wey don serve dis nation wit merit, man wey get strong character and convistion wey live life wit impact wey any pesin fit wish for, as e follow im well defined role for di growth of humanity and im untiring commitment for inside nation-building.

en: His contribution to the history of our nation and continent will never be forgotten
pcm: we no fit forget im contribution for di history of awa nation and continent

en: In the end,  as Abraham Lincoln succinctly asserts, it is not the years in one's life that count, but the life in one's years.
pcm: For di end, as Abraham Lincoln don assert, no be year inside pesin life count, di life wey dey inside pesin years.

en: May Allah SWT uplift his works and grant him Aljannar Firdaus.
pcm: Make Allah SWT uplift im work and grant am Aljannar Firdaus.

en: Muhammad Gombe, a media practitioner, writes from Abuja
pcm: Muhammad Gombe, wey be media practitioner, dey  write from inside Abuja

en: Benue warns of imminent food crisis
pcm: Benue dey warn say food crisis dey kom.

en: The Benue State Government at the weekend raised an alarm over imminent food crisis unless the challenges of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in various camps across the state were urgently addressed.
pcm: Di state goment inside Benue be raise alarm for weekend concernin food crisis wey fit apun unless dem address di challenge of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) dem for inside di state.

en: Executive Secretary of State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA), Dr. Emmanuel Shior, made the observation during an interactive session with newsmen in Makurdi.
pcm: Executive Secretary for State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA), Dr. Emmanuel Shior,  be make di observation for one toktok session wit newsmen for inside Makurdi.

en: Shior said it became necessary to sound the alarm as most of the IDPs are farmers who have been chased out of their ancestral lands occasioned by herders attacks for over two years now.
pcm: Shior tok e don bekom necessary to sound di alarm as many for inside di IDP be farmer wey dem don chase komot for dem ancestral land wey attack of herder dem kos for more than two years now.

en: The herders are the reason why the IDPs are in camps and till date, there are still pockets of attacks around Torkula and Idyer in Guma, Moor in Kwande, as well as some communities in Agatu and Logo, he said.
pcm: Na di herders be di reason why di IDP dey for camp till date, small small attack still dey apun for Torkula and Idyer inside Guma, Moor for Kwande, and some community for inside Agatu and Logo, as e tok am.

en: The SEMA boss said it was worrisome that the state has over 500,000 IDPs in eight designated camps across the state alongside others scattered in makeshift shelters in relatives homes while the state government continues to spend so much to fend for them.
pcm: Di oga for SEMA tok say e dey worrisome say di state get pass 500,000 IDPs for inside eight camp across di state along wit odas wey scatter for dem relative house as state goment kontinu to spend big to take care for dem.

en: He explained that, we have spent billions of naira in taking care of the IDPs since 2018.
pcm: He explain say, we don spend billions of naira to take care of IDP since 2018.

en: We have eight official camps housing over 500,000 IDPs in those camps.
pcm: We get eight official camp dem wey be house for over 500,000 IDP dem.

en: He however added that Governor Samuel Ortom had put in place the IDPs disengagement plans to ensure the safe return of the IDPs to their homes, noting that with the high number of IDPs in the state, it would be difficult to just close down the camps, especially as there were still pockets of attacks and their deserted homes not safe for return.
pcm: He however add say Governor Samuel Ortom don put di IDP disengagement plan down make sure say IDP dem return to dem house safe, e note say wit di kind high nomba of IDP for inside di state, e go dey difficult to just close camp down, especially as smallsmall attack dem still dey apun and dem house neva safe to return.

en: Shior appealed to the federal government, international donor partners as well as well-meaning individuals and corporate organizations to come to the aid of the state in that regard, stressing the need for the federal government to release the N10billion that was promised to Benue among other states for the resettlement of the IDPs.
pcm: Shior be beg federal goment, internation donor partner plus well-meanin individual and corporate organizations make dem kom help di state for dat regard, e stress di need for federal goment to release di N10billion wey dem promise Benue among oda state dem to take resettle IDPs.

en: 12 killed in fresh Benue attack
pcm: Dem kill 12 for fresh attack inside Benue

en: Gunmen have reportedly killed 12 people in several communities of Ado Local Government Area in Benue State.
pcm: Report be tok say gunmen don kill 12 pipo for inside several community of Ado Local Goment Area for Benue State.

en: Witnesses said the attack on the communities was carried out simultaneously between Saturday night and early hours of Sunday in Tologa, Ndi-Obasi, Odoken all in Ekile Council Ward of Ijigban District, Ado Local Government Area.
pcm: Witness dem tok say dem carry out di attack on top di community dem at di same time betwwen nite for Saturday and early morning for Sunday for Tologa, Ndi-Obasi, Odoken all inside Ekile Council Ward of Ijigban District, Ado Local Goment Area.

en: Chairman of Ado Council, James Oche, told journalists in Makurdi on telephone that 12 people were killed during a coordinated attack on five villages in his area.
pcm: Chairman of Ado Council, James Oche, tell journalist for Makurdi on telephone say dem kill 12 pipo durin one cordinated attack on five village dem for im area.

en: Oche alleged that the attack was a reprisal by suspected herders after some persons believed to be IPOB members crossed over from Ebonyi State to his Ado Local Government in Benue State and killed one elderly Fulani man identified as Muhammad Isah.
pcm: Oche allege say di attack na reprisal by herders wey dem suspect afta some pipo wey dem belif say dem be IPOB member be cross over from Ebonyi state to im Ado Local Goment for Benue State and dem kill one old Fulani man wey dem tok say na Muhammad Isah.

en: I suspect that the herders came on reprisal because of one elderly Fulani man known as Isah Muhammad who lived in one of the affected communities that shared boundary with Ohakwu Local Government Area of Ebonyi State and was recently killed by IPOB members, who crossed over to the comunity in Ado, he said.
pcm: I suspect say di herders be kom as reprisal bikos of one old Fulani man wey we konw as Muhammad Isah wey be dey live for one of di community dem wey dey affected wey dem share border wit Ohakwu Local Goment for Ebonyi State wey IPOB member dem just kill, dem cross ova kom di community for Ado, as he tok.

en: Contacted, the Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO) for Benue Command, DSP Catherine Anene, was yet to reply to calls and text messages put through her telephone at the time of sending this report.
pcm: Dem don contakt am, di Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO) for Benue Command, DSP Catherine Anene, neva reply to call and text message dem put through her telefone at di time wey we dey send dis report.

en: How local production of COVID-19 vaccine will save Nigeria
pcm: How to dey produce local covid-19 vaccine go take save Nigeria.

en: The federal government has reiterated the need to have a home-grown COVID-19 vaccine for its over 200 million population, saying local production of the vaccine would save the country the cost of importation as well as make it easily accessible and affordable.
pcm: Di federal goment don tok di need to have home-grown COVID-19 vaccine for im 200 million population, e tok say local production of di production of di vaccine go savedi kontri di cost of importation as well as say e dey easily accessible and affordible.

en: The Minister of state for Health, Dr Senator Olorunnimbe Mamora said that in order to achieve home-grown COVID-19 vaccines in Nigeria, there is a need to support research institutes.
pcm: DI minister of state on top health matter, Dr Senator Olorunnimbe Mamora tok say to achieve home grown COVID-19 vaccines for Nigeria, need dey to support research institute dem.

en: He said this on Monday at the Nigeria institute of medical research (NIMR), Lagos during the commissioning of the next generation sequencing as well as a tour of the projects within the institute.
pcm: Na for di Nigeria institute of medical research (NIMR) he tok am for Monday, for Lagos during di commissioning of di next generation sequencing as well a stour of di project withing di institute.

en: According to the Minister, Although there is a vaccine in the country, we will not stop research institutes from working on the one they are researching on.
pcm: According to di Minister, although vaccine be don dey for di kontri, we no go stop research institute dem from di one wey dem dey do resaerch put.

en: Having our own home-grown vaccine is the ultimate in which case, we don't have to look to any other country for a vaccine.
pcm: If we get awa own vaccine wey we do for awa home na di ultimate for which case, we no go dey look to any oda kontri for vaccine.

en: It is in our own interest that we ensure we get to that point where we can lay claim to our own vaccine.
pcm: Na for awa own interest say make we make sure say we reach dat point wey we fit claim awa own vaccine.

en: Nigeria and 53 other African countries are yet to produce a vaccine for over 1.34 billion people.
pcm: Nigeria and 54 oda kontri dem neva produce one vaccine for dem pipo wey pass 1.34 billion.

en: The continent is reliant on the vaccine produced from outside the continent.
pcm: Na vaccine wey dem produce outside di kontinent di kontinent dey rely on.

en: The Director-General/CEO of NIMR, Babatunde Salako, revealed that the institute has been having a collaboration with the Usmanu Danfodiyo University in Sokoto and the National Veterinary Institute in Jos for robust research on vaccine development in Nigeria.
pcm: Di Director-General/CEO of NIMR, Babatunde Salako, reveal say di institute don dey get collaboration with di Usmanu Danfodiyo University inside Sokoto and di National Veterinary Institute inside Jos for robust research on top  vaccine development for Nigeria.

en: Prof Salako hinted, While NIMR is currently using Gibson assembly cloning in developing multi-valent peptide subunit vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 virus, Usmanu Danfodiyo is employing bioinformatics and nano-technology to make DNA vaccines, and National Veterinary, on the other hand, is using reverse genetics in engineering New Castle Virus to express SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins.
pcm: Prof Salako be hint, as NIMR dey use Gibson assembly cloning for development multi-valent vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 virus  currently,  Usmanu Danfodiyo don dey employ bioinformatics and nanotechnology to take make DNA vaccines, and NationalVeterinary, for di oda hand, dey use reverse genetics for engineering New Castle Virus to express SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins.

en: This is a serious effort to be supported by the government.
pcm: Dis one na serious effort wey goment go support.

en: The newly commissioned sequencing machine, he explained, was acquired to serve in the molecular surveillance as well as monitor the variants of SARS-CoV-2 in Nigeria.
pcm: Di new sequencing machine wey dem just commission, im explain, dem buy to work on top di molecular surveillance and e go as well monitor di variant of SARS-CoV-2 for inside Nigeria.

en: The machine, he insisted, would prepare the country in the fight against other infectious agents such as Lassa fever virus, Yellow fever, Ebola and other infectious agents characterized by the genetic code.
pcm: Im insist say di machine go prepare di kontri to take fight against oda agent dem wey dey carry infection like lassa fever, Yellow fever, Ebola and oda infection agent dem wey genetic code dey characterize.

en: Gunmen abduct Nasarawa lawmaker, 3 others in Kaduna
pcm: Gunmen dem don carry lawmaker inside Nasarawa and 3 oda pipo for Kaduna

en: Unidentified gunmen have abducted a member of the Nasarawa State House of Assembly representing Nasarawa Central State Constituency, Mr Ismail Danbaba, his driver and two others to an unknown destination.
pcm: Gunmen wey dem no fit identify don carry member of Nasarawa STate House of Assembly wey det represent Nasarawa Central State Constituency, Mr Ismail Danbaba, im driver plus two oda pipo to place wey dem no know.

en: Daily Trust gathered that Danbaba, who was travelling to Jos, Plateau State capital for a workshop alongside his driver and two others people in his vehicle, was abducted on Saturday evening.
pcm: Daily Trust gather say Danbaba, wey dey travel go Jos, Plateau State capital for one workshop along im driver and two oda pipo for im vehicle, dem abduct am on Saturday evening.

en: The Chairman, Nasarawa State House of Assembly's Committee on Information, Mr Mohammed Omadefu, confirmed the incident in Lafia on Sunday.
pcm: Di Chairman, Nasarawa State House of Assembly Committee on top Information, Mr Mohammed Omadefu, confirm di incident for Lafia on Sunday.

en: He said the lawmaker was abducted along Akwanga/Jos road close to the forest in Sanga Local Government Area of Kaduna State.
pcm: He tok say dem carry di lawmaker along Akwanga/Jos road wey close to di forest for Sanga Local Goment Area of Kaduna State.

en: Our correspondent learnt the legislator was ambushed and whisked away to an unknown destination with his driver and two others in the vehicle.
pcm: Our correspondent hear sat dem ambush di legislator and dem carry dem away to destination wey dem neva know wit im driver and two oda for inside di vehicle.

en: Omadefu, who represents Keana State Constituency on the platform of the All Progressives Congress (APC), informed our correspondent that the lawmaker's abductors had already contacted the House but were yet to make demands.
pcm: Omadefu, wey dey represent Keana State Constituency on top di platform of  All Progressives Congress (APC), be inform awa correspondent say pipo wey abduct di lawmaker don contact im house but dem neva make demand.

en: He said: The lawmaker of the Nasarawa State House of Assembly, Mr Ismail Danbaba, who is representing Nasarawa Central, was kidnapped yesterday in the evening while he was on his way for an official function along Akwanga/Jos road in Sanga Local Government Area of Kaduna State.
pcm: He tok say: Di lawmaker for di Nasarawa State House of Assembly, Mr Ismail Danbaba, wey dey represent Nasarawa Central, na im dem kidnap yesterdayu for evenin wen im dey go one official function along Akwanga/Jos road for Sanga Local Goment Area inside Kaduna State.

en: When our correspondent contacted the Police Public Relation Officer, Nasarawa State Police Command, ASP Ramhman Nansel, he said the incident did not occur in Nasarawa State, so he would not comment on that.
pcm: Wen awa correspondent be contact di Police Public Relation Officer, Nasarawa State Police Command, ASP Ramhman Nansel, he tok say di incident no apun for inside Nasarawa state, so im no go tok on am.

en: He said: Please, contact the Police Public Relation Officer in Kaduna state.
pcm: He tok say: Abeg contact di Police Public Relation Officer for inside Kaduna State.

en: Nasarawa State command is not aware of any such incident.
pcm: Nasarawa stete command no dey aware of any kind incident.

en: 4 killed in police faceoff with IPOB sit-at-home enforcers in Ebonyi
pcm: Dem kill 4 as police face-of with wit pipo wey dey enforce  IPOB sit-for-home matta for inside Ebonyi

en: Four people are feared killed in shooting between members of Indigenous Peoples of Biafra and police in Ebonyi.
pcm: Dem dey fear say dem don kill four pipo for shooting between member of Indigenous Peoples of Biafra and police for Ebonyi.

en: Early indications are that a police officer and three IPOB members are among those killed, though Daily Trust is unable to independently verify the identities and the numbers.
pcm: Early indicator na say dem kill one police officer and three IPOB member dey among di one wey dem kill, although Daily Trust neva get chance to verify di identity and nomba.

en: The shooting occurred in Nnodo in Ebonyi local government area of Ebonyi state where police encountered IPOB members enforcing the group's sit-at-home order.
pcm: Di shootin apun for Nnodo inside Ebonyi local goment area of Ebonyi State wia police face IPOB member dem wey dey enforce di sit-at-home order from di group.

en: A reliable source who doesn't want his name on print told Daily Trust that motorbikes and cars were set ablaze during the attack.
pcm: Asource wey dey reliable wey no want make dem write im name tell Daily Trust say dem burn okada and car during di attack.

en: And in order to stop them, the police was mobilized to the area leading to shooting during which deaths were recorded, he explained.
pcm: And in order to take stop dem, dem mobilise di police go di area and e enter shootin level and pipo, na so he explain.

en: The police are yet to put out any official statement on the incident.
pcm: Di police neva put out any official statement on top di incident.

en: FULL LIST: The 30 guests that will attend Prince Philip's funeral
pcm: FULL LIST: Di 30 guest wey go attend Prince Philip funeral

en: Only 30 guests will be present when Prince Philip, the late husband of Queen Elizabeth, will be laid to rest.
pcm: Na only 30 guests go dey present when dem go lay Prince Philip, di husband of Queen Elizabeth to rest.

en: Aged 99, Prince Philip died after a brief illness on Friday.
pcm: Prince Philip wey be 99 years die afta small sickness for Friday.

en: Due to the coronavirus pandemic, members of the public were advised not to partake in the funeral.
pcm: Due to coronavirus pandemic, dem advise member of di public say make dem no follow for di funeral.

en: The Queen reportedly faced a very difficult decision selecting the small group from the original 800-strong congregation of St George's Chapel in Windsor, West of London, where Prince Philips will be laid to rest.
pcm: Di queen as report say face very difficult decision to take selekt di small group from di original 800-strong congregation of St George's Chapel for windsor, West London, wia dem go lay Prince Philip to rest.

en: Here is the guest list in full
pcm: Na di list be dis in full

en: Issues FG must fix to regain cotton glory
pcm: Issue dem wey FG must fix to regain glory inside cotton matta

en: In the last two years, cotton production has been gathering momentum, but the challenges of farmers have remained unsolved.
pcm: For di last two years, di production of cotton don dey gather momentum, but dem neva solve di challenge wey farmer dem dey face.

en: Cotton farmers in Nigeria are mostly smallholders, with production largely through the rain-fed system, using traditional farm tools and animal traction (animal drawn implements).
pcm: Farmer wey dey farm cotton mostly na smallholders, and production na largely through rain-fed system, using traditional farm tools and animal traction (animal drawn implements).

en: However, few now have access to tractors.
pcm: However, few don get access to tractor.

en: In the 1980s, cotton was grown by about 900,000 smallholder farmers, holding an average of 0.5 to 1.5 hectares in an estimated total area of about 700,000 hectares across the country.
pcm: For late 1980s, e reach 900,000 smallholder dem wey dey grow cotton, den hold average of 0.5 to 1.5 hectare for di total area wey dem estimate as 700,000 hectare across di kontri.

en: However, with the collapse of the textile and garment industries, as well as poor market, most of the farmers abandoned production for other crops with better market potentials.
pcm: However, as di textile and garment industry don collapse, plus poor market, most of di farmer dem abandon production enter oda crop dem wey get better market.

en: Current production level
pcm: Current production level

en: The annual demand of cotton in Nigeria is estimated at 88,000 metric tonnes of lint, which is about 255,000 metric tonnes of seed cotton.
pcm: Dem estimate di annual demand of cotton for Nigeari at 88,000 metric tonnes of lint, wey reach 225,000 metric tonnes of seed cotton.

en: Until 2019, the total domestic production was below 60,000 with many farmers struggling even to achieve the average yield of between 400kg and 750kg of seed cotton per hectare despite the fact that some of the seeds have yield prospects of about 2.5 to 3.0 metric tonnes per hectare.
pcm: Until 2019, di total domestic production dey below 60,000 as plenty farmer dem dey struggle to achieve di average yield of between 400kg and 750kg of seed cotton per hectare despite di fact say some of di field prospect of about 2.5 to 3.0 metric tonne per hectare.

en: Statistics from the National Cotton Association of Nigeria (NACOTAN) showed that the number of farmers under the association has grown from 90,000 in 2018 to about 134,000 farmers for the 2020 wet season.
pcm: Statistics from di National Cotton Association of Nigeria (NACOTAN) show say di nomba of farmer dem under di association don grow from 90,000 for 2018 reach 134,000 farmer dem for di 2020 wet season.

en: In 2019, the farmers achieved 120,000 to 130,000 tonnes, which amounts to about 80,000 metric tonnes increase.
pcm: For 2019, di farmers dem achieve 120,000 to 130,000 tonnes, wey amount reach increase of about 80,000 metric tonnes.

en: For this 2020 wet season, production was expected to reach 200,000 metric tonnes, according to NACOTAN.
pcm: For inside dis 2020 wet season, dem expekt make production reach 200,000 metric tones, accordinto NACOTAN.

en: The current market
pcm: Di current market

en: A farmer, Bala Sarkin Ruwa in Shelleng, Adamawa State, told Daily Trust on Sunday that he sold the 2 tons of his cotton early at N180,000.
pcm: A farmer, Bala Sarkin Ruwa for Shelleng, inside Adamawa State, tell Daily Trust on Sunday say e sell di two ton of im cotton early for 180,000.

en: But his counterpart, Mr Joshua Dadi said he sold at N200,000 in January 2021, describing the price as fair.
pcm: But im counterpart, Mr Joshua Dadi tok say he sell for N200,000 for January 2021, he describe di price say e fair.

en: Mr Anibe Achimugu, national president of the NACOTAN and managing director of the Arewa Cotton, described the current prices as good for the farmers, compared to previous years.
pcm: Mr Anibe Achimugu, national president of di NACOTAN and managing director for ARewa Cotton describe di current price say e good for farmer dem, if dem compare to previous one.

en: In 2019, the price per tonne was N205,000 for farmers.
pcm: For 2019, di price for one tonne be N205,000 for farmer dem.

en: That means a farmer was doing over a N100,000 profits directly into the pocket if he was able to produce 2 tonnes of seed cotton.
pcm: Dat one mean say one farmer be dey do over 100,000 profit directly into di pocket if e dey able to poduce 2 tonnes of seed cotton.

en: The intervention is such that the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) wants to jump-start the sector.
pcm: Di intervention an such say di Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) wan jump start di sector.

en: And of course, you want to leave it, to a large extend, at market-driven prices and demand.
pcm: And of course, you wan leave am, to large extend, for market-driven price dem and demand.

en: Now, the minimum price, at least this year, is N185,000 per metric tonne, which is still better than if it was to be left on its own and not encouraging to farmers, and so on, where prices were N140 to N150,000 per metric tonne.
pcm: Now, di minimum price, at least for dis year, na N185,000 per metric tonne, wey still better pass make dem leave am on im ownand e no go encourage farmer dem, and so on, wia price dem be N150,000 per metric tonne.

en: I think the minimum guaranteed price since the intervention has been good, he said.
pcm: I thingk say di minimum price wey dem guarantee since di intervention be don dey good, as e tok am.

en: Issue of quality seed
pcm: Issue of quality seed

en: Professor Ishiyaku Mohammed, the executive director of the Institute of Agricultural Research, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, said the institute had released13 different varieties of cotton seeds with very important economic attributes that increase the income of farmers and provide different products for utilisation, either as fiber or for making textile products, or even for providing oil.
pcm: Professor Ishiyaku Mohammed, the executive director for di Institute of Agricultural Research, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, tok say di institute don release 13 different variants of cotton seed dem wey get veri important economic attribute dat increase di income of farmer and provide different product for utilisation, either as fibre or for making textile product dem, or to even to provide oil.

en: The farmers said that last year, there was an improved access to better quality seeds, with a potential yield of 2.5 tonne per hectare if the best agronomic practices were followed.
pcm: Di farmer dem tok say lats year, dem access to better seed wey get quality dey improved, wey get potential yirld of 2.5 tonne per hactareif dem follow di best agronomic practice.

en: With that, Achimugu said a farmer was jumping in yield figure of between 400 to 500 kilogrammes per hectare to 1.2, 1.5, and in fact, some were getting the 2.5 tonne per hectare.
pcm: With dat, Achimugu tok say a farmer be dey jump for yield figure between 400 to 500 kilogram per hectare to 1.2, 1.5 and in fact, some be dey get reach 2.5 tonne per hectare.

en: You know it is how well you manage your farm, the dedication and skill you have, but I will tell you specifically that perhaps the lowest that was recorded was around 700 to 750kg per hectare.
pcm: You know say na how well you take manage your farm, di dedication plus skil wey you get, but i go tell you specifically say di lowest wey we record na around 700 to 750kg per hectare.

en: But farmers were hitting 1.5 to 2.5 tonnes per hectare, which was fantastic.
pcm: But farmer dem be dey hit 1.5 to 2.5 tonnes per hectare, e dey fantastic.

en: In  2018, the federal government, through  the National Varietal Release and Naming Committee, approved the commercialisation of two transgenic cotton varieties, MRC 7377 BG 11 and MRC 7361 BG II developed by Mahyco Nigeria Private Ltd, in collaboration with the Institute for Agricultural Research (IAR) in the Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria.
pcm: For 2018, di gederal goment, through di National Varietal Release and Naming Committee, be approve commercialisation of two transgenetic variety of cotton, MRC 7377 BG 11 and MRC 7361 BG II wey Mahyco Nigeria Private Ltd develop, as dem collabo wit di Institute for Agricultural Research (IAR) in di Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria.

en: Resuscitating cotton industry, a lifeline
pcm: To resuscitate cotton industry, a lifeline

en: Cotton is the key component of the textile and garment industries because it provides fibre for the manufacturing of textile products.
pcm: Cotton na key component for di textile and garment industry dem bikos e dey provide fibre to take manufacture textile product dem.

en: However, the faith of the nations textile industries had gone down to a pulp for decades since the glorious years.
pcm: However, di faith wey di taxtile industry get for inside di nation don go down to pulp for decade since di glorious years.

en: In the 1970s to the 1990s, the Nigerian textile industry accounted for about 25 per cent of the Manufacturing Value Added (MVA).
pcm: For di 1970s and di 1980s, di Nigeria textile industry be account for about 25 per cent of di manufacturing value added (MVA).

en: It used to be the largest employer of labour (more than 600,000 people during the 1970s to 1980s) in the manufacturing sector after public sector in the early 1990s.
pcm: Na be largest employer of labour (e pass  600,000 people during the 1970s to 1980s) for di manufacturing sector afta public sector for di early 1990s.

en: However, experts hinged the collapse of the textile industries that made Kaduna a household name in the country on the high operating cost, resulting from poor energy supply, infrastructure decay and proliferation of the market with cheap and smuggled textiles.
pcm: However, expert don see di collapse of di textile industry wey turn Kaduna to household name for di kontri as high operating cost, wey dey result from poor energy supply, decay of infrastructure and proliferation of di market with textile dem wey cheap and di one wey dem smuggle.

en: This also forced some to relocate to other countries within the sub-region.
pcm: Dem also force some to relocate go oda kontri dem withing di sub-region.

en: Out of the 54 ginneries available in Nigeria, only 22 are functioning at very low capacity utilisation.
pcm: Among di 54 ginneries wey dey avilable for Nigeria, Only 22 dey function for very low capacity utilisation.

en: Ginning capacity of the existing ginneries is about 650,000 tonnes of seed cotton but national production falls to less than 60,000 tonnes per annum representing about 10 per cent capacity utilisation according to the data from the Raw Material Research and Development Council (RMRDC).
pcm: Di ginning capacity for di ginneries wey dey exist na about 650,000 tonnes of seed cotton but national production dey fall to less than 60,000 tonnes per year wey dey represent about 10 per cent capacity utilisation accordin by di data from di Raw Material Research and Development Council (RMRDC).

en: This trend has a spirally limiting effect on the cotton value chain development locally, culminating in the folding up of several textile industries (83) between 1995 till date, while the few that are functioning (23) are performing at low capacity utilisation, Professor Hassaini Ibrahim Doko, the director-general, RMRDC said.
pcm: Dis trend get spirally limiting effekt on top di cotton value chain development localy, na im add to take kos make plenty textile industry (83) fold up between 1995 reach now, as di few wey dey function dey perform for low capacity utilisation, as Professor Hassaini Ibrahim Doko, the director-general, RMRDC tok.

en: Experts said to bring cotton value chain back to life and its glorious days, the federal government must champion the revival of industries through various policies and financial interventions.
pcm: Expert tok say to bring cotton value chain back to life and im glorious day dem, di federal goment must to champion di revival of industry dem wit many many policy dem and financial intervention.

en: FG must tackle smuggling, cheap import
pcm: FG must to tackle smuggling, cheap import

en: The Director-General of the Nigerian Textile Manufacturers Association, Alhaji Hamma Kwajaffa, said smuggling and cheap Chinese imports had been the bane of the country's cotton industry.
pcm: Di Director-General for di Nigerian Textile Manufacturers Association, Alhaji Hamma Kwajaffa, tok say smuggling plus cheap Chinese product na di probblem for cotton industry inside di kontri.

en: Despite the procurement act for local content to be sourced first, nothing has changed much as most of the materials used for uniforms majorly come from China, while others come from India, Bangladesh and Pakistan.
pcm: Despite say procurement act dey say make dem dey look for local content first, nothingg don change much as plenty inside di material wey dem dey use for uniform dey kom from China, as oda dem dey kom from China, Bangladesh and Pakistan.

en: The original thing should have been that all our uniforms are sourced locally from the textile companies.
pcm: Di original thing suppose be say we dey source all awa uniform locally from di textile kompany dem.

en: If you look at our schools, Army, Navy, Air Force, Immigration, Customs etc, if their uniforms were all sourced locally, of course many of the textile industries would not have closed.
pcm: If you look awa school dem, Army, Navy, Air Force, Immigration, Customs etc, if dem dey source dem uniform locally, of kos many of di textile industry no for close.

en: Our problem is actually smuggling.
pcm: Smuggling na awa actual problem.

en: You know our dealers can go to China; and in China, anything you ask for they can do it for you.
pcm: You know say dealer fit go China; and for China, anything wey you ask for, dem fit do am for you.

en: They go to China with our textile design and the Chinese would do it for them the way they want, and this ends up in Nigerian markets, Alhaji  Kwajaffa lamented.
pcm: Dem dey go China wit awa textile design and di Chinese go do am for dem as dem take want am, and dis go end up for market inside Nigeria, Alhaji  Kwajaffa lament.

en: Cotton farmers, through the NACOTAN, want the federal government to take up cotton as a national asset and introduce a Nigerian standard, which can help the country to have a good grading system, as well as the establishment of high volume instrument cotton testing laboratories, he also said, adding that these will take care of many issues.
pcm: Cotton farmer, through NACOTAN want make federal goment take cotton up as national asset and make dem introduce Nigeria standard, wey fit help di kontri get better gradin system, as well as to establish laboratory wey dem go take dey test cotton wit high volume instrument, e also tok say na dis one go take care of di issue dem.

en: Banditry affects production
pcm: Bandit dem affect production.

en: In the last two years, many cotton farmers could not access their farms because of the activities of bandits along major producing areas.
pcm: For di last two years, plenty cotton farmer dem no fit reach dem farm, bikos of di things wey bandit dem dey do along major production area dem.

en: Recently, the only surviving textile company in Kaduna State shut down operations and sacked over 100 staff due to the absence of raw materials because the farmers were complaining that bandits won't allow them go to their farms.
pcm: E neva tey, wey di only textile company wey dey survive for inside Kaduna State be shut down operation and dem sack pass 100 staff bikos say raw material no dey as di farmer dem dey complain say bandit dem no allow dem reach farm.

en: Stakeholders said government must reinvigorate its security architecture to enable farmers return to their farms as that is the only way to reduce poverty in rural communities.
pcm: Stakeholder dem tok say make goment ginger dem security architecture make farmer dem fit return to dem farm as dat one na di only way to take reduce poverty for rural community dem.

en: Abdullahi Salisu Dayi, a farmer in Malumfashi Local Government, said that unless something spectacular happened in favour of cotton production, he doubted if farmers would engage in it as they did last year.
pcm: Abdullahi Salisu Dayi, farmer for  inside Malumfashi Local Goment, tok say unless some wey dey spectacular apun to take favour di production of cotton, e doubt am if farmer dem go wan do am as dem do last year.

en: Climate change affecting production
pcm: Climate change wey dey affect production

en: Last year, many cotton farmers in Katsina, Gombe and Adamawa states suffered erratic rainfall, which has affected yields.
pcm: Last year, many cotton farmer for inside Katsina, Gombe and Adamawa state dem be suffer erratic rainfall, wey do affect yield.

en: Some farmers who spoke with Daily Trust on Sunday in Adamawa, Katsina and Gombe said their yields were severely affected by little or heavy rainfall.
pcm: Some farmer dem wey speak wit Daily Trust on Sunday for Adamawa, Katsina and Gombe tok say heavy rainfall be affect dem yield welwel.

en: Joshua Dadi in Kem, Adamawa State, said his yield was affected because of a sudden cessation of rainfall.
pcm: Joshua Dadi for Kem, Adamawa State, tok say im yield dey affected bikos say rain stop suddenly.

en: Although he got 4 tonnes in his two-hectare farm, the yield is below the 2019 yield.
pcm: Although he get 4 tonnes for im two-hectare farm, di yield no reach di yield of 2019.

en: Hamisu Sani in Katsina said cotton farmers suffered most as demand for the produce is not like that of rice, maize or soybeans, yet its price is good at N200,000 per tonne.
pcm: Hamisu Sani for Katsina tok say cotton farmer dem suffer most as di demand for di produce no be like as e be for rice, maize or soybeans, yet di price dey good for N200,000 per tonne.

en: Heavy rainfalls permeated our cotton farms and stagnated the growth of the crop, as well as caused rot of the cotton balls at their early stage, he added.
pcm: He add say plenty rain wey fall be enter awa farm and e stop di crop to grow, and e also make di cotton ball make dem rotten for early stage.

en: Another large scale cotton farmer, Alhaji Kamilu Kankara, said he also suffered low yield of the produce due to heavy rainfall.
pcm: Anoda farmer wey dey grow cotton for large scale, Alhaji Kamilu Kankara, tok say im also suffer low yield of di produce bikos say rain fall plenty.

en: Over the years, demand for food items has prompted my gradual withdrawal from massive cotton production.
pcm: Over di years, demand wey dey on top food don prompt make I withdraw gradually from massive cotton production.

en: This year seems the worst for me as I only harvested nine bags from two hectares that were giving me three tonnes of cotton, he said.
pcm: E be like say na dis year worst pass for me as I harvest only nine bags from inside two hectare wey be dey give three tonnes of cotton, as e take tok am.

en: With a growing population of over 200 million and army of unemployed youth roaming the streets, experts said government must give priority to sectors like agriculture huge attention, both in budget, policies and financial interventions.
pcm: With population wey don grow pass 200 million and army of youth wey no get job wey dey waka for street, expert dem be tok make goment give priority to sector like agriculture big attention, both for budget, policies and financial intervention dem.

en: Cocoa production is not progressing in Edo  Farmers
pcm: Farmers Cocoa production no dey progress for Edo

en: Cocoa farmers in Edo State have lamented that lack of support from the state and federal governments is hindering cocoa production in the state.
pcm: Cocoa farmer dem for inside Edo State don lament say lack of support from di state and federal goment dey hinder cocoa production for inside di state.

en: The state chairman of the association, Thomas Ekpenriebe, stated this in Benin while speaking with journalists on the prospect of cocoa farming in the state.
pcm: Di state chairman of di assocition, Thomas Ekpenriebe, be state dis for Benin wen im dey follow journalist tok on top di prospect of cocoa farming for di state.

en: He said the farmers had not gotten any support from either the state government or the Federal Government, in term of inputs and funding, saying the development is really affecting cocoa production in the state.
pcm: He tok say di farmer dem neva get any support from either di state goment or di Federal goment, like input and funding, e tok say di development be dey affect cocoa production for di state.

en: As it is now in Edo State, we go to Ibadan and Ondo states to get the new hybrid of cocoa because the cocoa seed garden in the state is not functioning, and nobody is managing it.
pcm: As e dey now for Edo, we dey Ibadan and Ondo State to get new hybrid cocoa bikos di cocoa seed garden for inside di state no dey function, and nobody dey mange am.

en: Also, there is no extension service for cocoa farmers in the state.
pcm: Also, extension service no dey for cocoa farmer dem for di state.

en: In the 1960s, cocoa was the cash crop used to develop the country.
pcm: For di 1960s, cocoa na im be di cash crop wey dem use to develop di kontri.

en: Today, there's nothing coming from the state or Federal Government.
pcm: Today, nothing dey kom from di state or federal goment.

en: We are just working on our own and it is affecting cocoa production in the state and the country in general, he said.
pcm: We just dey work on awa own and e dey affect cocoa production for di state and di kontri in general, as e take tok.

en: The farmers solicited the support of the Edo State Government to invest in cocoa farming by reawakening extension service, re-established cocoa seed garden to avoid travelling to other states for seedlings and also generate more revenue for the state.
pcm: Di farmer dem call for support from di Edo State Goment to invest put for cocoa farming by make dem wake di extension service again, make dem re-establish cocoa seed garden to take avoid travel to oda state dem for seed and also to take generate more money for di state.

en: The chairman also lamented the activities of middlemen in cocoa business in the state, which he said was affecting profits accrued to cocoa.
pcm: Di chairman be also lament about di acitivity of middlemen dem inside cocoa business for di state, wey im tok say dey affekt di profit wey dey on top cocoa.

en: While calling for the re-establishment of a cocoa board across the country, he said, The board would serve as a regulatory body that would help cocoa farmers to identify licensed buyers and control the price of the commodities.
pcm: When im dey call say make dem re-establish cocoa board all over di kontri, di board go serve as regulatory bodi wey go help cocoa farmer dem to know buyer wey get license and regulate price for di commodity.

en: He explained that currently, Edo State has the best quality cocoa due to the concerted efforts by relevant stakeholders.
pcm: He explain say currently, na Edo State get di best quality cocoa due to di concerned effort by stakeholder dem.

en: Ekpenriebe also identified unfavourable climate, outbreak of fire, COVID-19, absence of a regulatory body as major hindrances to the sector.
pcm: Ekpenriebe also point finger for climate wey no dey favour, COVID-19 plus say regulatory bodi no dey as major block for di sector.

en: Entrepreneurship development: Purpose and mindset
pcm: Development on top entrepreneurship: Purpose and mindset

en: After the arrival of the colonial masters to various parts of what later became Nigeria, and the beginning of the introduction of Western-style public administration, the need for trained native public servants began.
pcm: Afta colonial master dem arrive enter various part of wetin later bekom Nigeria, and di begining of introduction of Western-style administration, di need to train native oublic servant start.

en: With increasing need for various services, the vacancies for trained manpower continued to balloon for several decades up to the 1980s.
pcm: As need for various service dey increase, di vacancy dem for trained manpower kontinu to dey plenty for many decadego reach di 1980s.

en: But by the late 1980s, we had begun to not only saturate the public services, but were probably over-employed.
pcm: But for late 1980s, we don begin not to just dey saturate di public service dem, but be like dem don employ too much.

en: If any realistic and prudent thing is to happen to our public services over the next one decade, it should be a deliberate and systemic rightsizing, and that is a polite way of saying downsizing except probably for the military, the police and other such services.
pcm: If any realistic and prudent thing go apun to awa public service dem ova di next one decade, e go be delibrate and systemic rightsizing, and dat na di polite way to say downsizing except for di military, di police and oda such service dem.

en: Yes, obviously, people will die or retire and there will be need to employ for replacements and for some marginal growth as well.
pcm: Yes, obviously, pipo go die or make dem retire and need go dey to employ for replacement and for some kind marginal growth too.

en: But those combined vacancies are very unlikely to meet up with the rate graduates from high schools and universities are churned out from all around the country.
pcm: But di vacancies combined no dey likely to meet up wit di rate graduates from high school and university dey komot from all around di kontri.

en: We have to, therefore, not only accept the reality that the public sector is never meant to be there to just employ graduates but to also gladly accept the truism that the public sector should, instead, focus on developing the enabling environment that will see to the creation and growth of businesses of all sizes in all sectors and crannies of the country.
pcm: We have to, therefore, no be to accept di reality say di public sector neva suppose dey dere to just to employ graduates alone but also to gladly accept di truism say di public sector suppose, instead, focus on to develop di enabling environment wey go see to di creation and growth of business of all size dem for all sector and crany of di kontri.

en: If you ask me, successive federal governments in the past have done reasonably well in encouraging graduates to go into self-employment and business through programs with the Bank of Agriculture, Bank of Industry, SMEDAN, NDE, NIRSAL, etc.
pcm: If you ask me, successive federal goment dem for di past don do well to take encourage graduates to enter sef-develoment and business through program dem wit di Bank of Agriculture, Bank of Industry, SMEDAN, NDE, NIRSAL, etc.

en: But the call has not been sufficiently loud and unequivocal: The government must cease creating any impressions that it can directly employ the multitudes of our youths, by honestly and clearly communicating that there are limited employment opportunities in the public sector that can come up from time to time.
pcm: But di call neva dey sufficiently loud and equivocal: Di goment must cease to dey create any impression say e fit employ di plenty youth , make dem honest and communicate clearly say employment opportunity dem dey limited for di public sector wey fit dey komot from time to time.

en: Instead, the government should continue to focus on strengthening the various interventionist and enabling programmes that will facilitate the creation of employment by the youth themselves.
pcm: Instead, make di goment kontinu dey focus on top to streghten di various interventionist and enabling program dem wey go facilitate di creation of employmeny by youth demsef.

en: Obviously, all the aforementioned programmes can only succeed and be sustainable if a sense and responsibility of accountability are both inculcated and enforced in our youth.
pcm: Obviously, all di program wey we donmention before fit only succeed and dem go dey sustainable if dem put a sense of responsibility of accountability for inside pou youth.

en: With a population of over two hundred million people and growing, there are more than sufficient local markets for many products and services.
pcm: Wit population wey pass two hundred million pipo and e still dey grow, more than sufficient local market dem dey for plenty product and service dem.

en: From abundant fertile land for agriculture all across the country, to solid minerals in most states of the federation; information technology, manufacturing and services, we really are literally a bottomless pit of opportunities for serious entrepreneurs.
pcm: From abundant land wey dey fertile for agriculture all across di kontri, reach solid minerals inside most state of di federation; information technology, manufacturing and services, we be plenty opportunity for entrepreneurs wey seriuos.

en: Over the coming weeks, this column would endeavour to bring out topical issues on entrepreneurship that will help our youths in understanding opportunities and how to seize them and create jobs for themselves and others.
pcm: Ova weeks wey dey kom, dis column go try to bring out topical issue on top entrepreneurship wey go help awa youth to understand opportunities amd how to take seize dem and create jib for demsef and odas.

en: The starting points for the success of any and every worthy endeavour in life are two: purpose and mind-set.
pcm: Di starting point for any and evri endeavour wey dey worthy in life na two: purpose and mind-set.

en: One of the reasons many people fail to achieve meaningful and sustainable success in business and life is because they fail to identify their life's purpose from the get-go.
pcm: One of di reason wey plenty pipo fail to achieve maeningful and sustainable success for inside business and life na bikos dem fail to identify di purpose of dem life from di begining.

en: Even when they can boast of what might seem to be reasonable outwardly achievements, they may still lack the full internal satisfaction necessary to keep them motivated and going for the marathon this life is.
pcm: Even when dem fit boast of wetin be like outward achievement wey dey reasonable, dem fit still lack di internal satisfaction wey dey neccessary to kip dem motivated and going for di marathon wey dis life be.

en: Lack of purpose costs us resources such as our time, finances, efforts, relationships, etc.
pcm: Na lack of purpose be dey make us loss resources like awa time, money, effir dem, relationship, etc.

en: In the long run, we realise that it has deprived us of true meaning in the various spheres of our lives and the contentment that comes with it.
pcm: For di long run, we realise say e don deprive us of true meaning for di various sphere of awa lives and di cintentment wey go follow am kom.

en: Without a purpose or with a weak one, an individual can easily be swayed away from their otherwise noble journey.
pcm: Without any purpose or wit a weak one, e dey easy for pesin to sway komot form dem noble journey.

en: Entrepreneurship is particularly challenging.
pcm: Entrepreneurship dey particularly challenging

en: Without a clear purpose that has deep meaning that is internalised, you risk missing your way or giving up when you hit headwinds, and there will be a lot of it in the journey!
pcm: If clear purpose wey get deep meaning wey dem internalise, you risk to miss your way or to give up when you hit headwinds, and plenty of am go dey for di journey!

en: The next most important thing after purpose is your mindset.
pcm: Di next thing wey dey most important afta purpose na your mindset.

en: Consciously or subconsciously, everything starts with our mind-sets.
pcm: Either we know abi we no know, evrithing dey start wit awa mindset.

en: Successful entrepreneurs have an amazing perception of what they want to achieve years and even decades before it becomes reality.
pcm: Successful entrepreneurs have an amazing perception of what dey want to achieve years and even decades before it becomes reality. Entrepreneur dem wey dey successful get perception wey dey amazing on top di thing wey dem wan achieve years and decades even before e go bekom reality.

en: It is the clarity of the vision in their minds that keeps them highly motivated internally and quite relentless on the outside.
pcm: Na di clearity of di vision wey dey dem mind dey kip motivation for dem inside and dem no dey show say dem tire outside.

en: And so nothing seems to be able to stop them.
pcm: And so e be like say nothing fit stop dem.

en: In the conceptual development and production of the Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the American Walt Disney faced an unbelievable resistance from financiers, contributors and other associates including his brother, Roy Disney.
pcm: For di conceptual development and production of di Snow White and di Seven Dwarfs, DI America pesin Walt Disney be face resistance wey no dey believable from financier dem, contributor and oda associate dem, include im broda, Roy Disney.

en: Hollywood wags referred to the project as Disney's Folly.
pcm: Gossip pipo for inside Hollywood dey call di project say na Disney's Folly.

en: But Disney was very clear in his mind as to what he wanted to achieve.
pcm: But Disney dey very clear for im mind on top wetin im be wan achieve.

en: He refused to lose focus on his desired outcome.
pcm: Im no gree to make im focus komot for di outkom wey im desire.

en: In the end, the project cost a whopping 1.5 million in 1938 US dollars.
pcm: For di end, di projekt be cost whopping 1.5 million US dollars of 1938.

en: But in the first weekend of its release, Snow White brought in $8 million, representing about $134 million in current dollars!
pcm: But for di first weekend wey dem release am, Snow White bring $8 million, wey be like $134 million for current dollar!

en: This level of confidence is never accidental.
pcm: Dis level for confidnece neva no fit be by accident.

en: It is a consequence of a mindset that is committed to achieving identified objectives.
pcm: Na consequence of mindset wey don commit say e go achieve some goal dem wey dem don identify.

en: Ask any successful entrepreneur, they will identify with this story of vision, mind-set and resolve.
pcm: Ask any entrepreneur wey don dey successful, dem go gree wit dis tori on top vision, mindset and resolve.

en: With a clear purpose and a committed mindset, the next important thing the budding entrepreneur should be aware of is what to expect in entrepreneurship.
pcm: Wit clear purpose and mindset wey dey committed, di nect thing wey budding entrepreneur need to aware about na what dem go expekt for entrepreneurship.

en: Entrepreneurship: What to Expect on the Journey will be in this column next week.
pcm: Entrepreneurship: Wetin you must expect for inside di journey go dey dis column next week.

en: Musbahu El Yakub is an author, business consultant and entrepreneur.
pcm: Musbahu El Yakub na author, business consultant and entrepreneur.

en: Niger Senator wants electronic voting mandatory for 2023 polls
pcm: Senator for inside Niger want make dem compulsory electric votin for 2023 election

en: The Senator representing Niger East Senatorial District, Mohammed Sani Musa, has advocated mandatory use of electronic voting during the 2023 general elections.
pcm: Di Senator wey dey represent Niger East Senatorial District, Mohammed Sani Musa, don advocate compulsory use of electronic voting durin di 2023 general election dem.

en: Speaking with newsmen on Monday in Abuja, Senator Musa said electronic voting would increase participation in elections as it would allow voters to vote from anywhere.
pcm: As e dey follow news pipo tok on Monday for inside Abuja, Senator Musa tok say electronic voting go increase participation for election as e go allow make voter dem vote from anywia.

en: The lawmaker therefore urged the Senate Committee on Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) working on the amendments to the Electoral Act 2010, to include the mandatory use of electronic voting during elections, in their final report to the senate at plenary.
pcm: Di lawmaker therefore dey urge di Committee inside Senate wey concern  Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) wey dey do work on top amendment of Electoral Act 2010, to include make dem compulsory di use electronic voting for inside dem final report to di senate at plenary.

en: Senate President Ahmad Lawan had said that the National Assembly would pass the amendment to the Bill before the Summer Recess which is in June.
pcm: Senate President Ahmad Lawan don tok say di National Assembly go pass di amendment of di bill before di summer recess wey be June.

en: Electronic voting will increase the level of participation because it will allow them to vote from anywhere.
pcm: Electronic voting go increase di level wey pipo dey take participate bikos e go allow make dem vote for anywia.

en: It will also eliminate violence because the majority of people who have access to the internet will prefer to vote in their homes or offices instead of going physically to the polling stations where armed thugs could cause havoc, he said.
pcm: E tok say e go also komot violence bikos di majoruty of pipo wey fit access di internet go prefer make dem vote for dem house or office dem instead make dem go polling station wey armed thug dem fit kos havoc.

en: Grazing crisis: Why states should adopt Zamfara template
pcm: Grazing wahala: why make state dem follow Zamfara template

en: Kwagga Dlama Zira Eliphelet is an architect, designer and project manager of the Zamfara Rural Grazing Area (RUGA) project.
pcm: Kwagga Dlama Zira Eliphelet na architect, designer and projekt manager for di Zamfara Rural Grazing Area (RUGA) projekt.

en: In this interview with Daily Trust on Sunday, he said the Zamfara model could be used in solving the crisis between herders and farmers across the country.
pcm: For dis interview wit Daily Trust on Sunday, he tok say dem fit use di model of Zamfara to take solve di crisis between herders and farmers across di kontri.

en: He is of the opinion that the template can be best implemented based on the peculiarity of each state, with the overall interest of creating peace, jobs and economic opportunities.
pcm: Im opinion na say di best way to take implement di template na base on di peculiarity of each state, wit di overall interest of creating peace, jobs and economic opportunities.

en: There is crisis in the livestock sector in Nigeria, especially in the area of animal feeds.
pcm: Crisis dey di livestock sector for Nigeria, especially for di area of animal feeds.

en: Many stakeholders are suggesting that one of the ways forward is to create ranches for herders in order to tame grazing crisis with farmers.
pcm: Plenty stakeholder dey suggest say one of di to move forward na to create ranches for herders to take tame grazing crisis wit farmer dem.

en: As an expert in this area, to what extent do you think this can help?
pcm: As expert for dis area, to what extent you thingk say dis fit help?

en: The incessant farmers-herders crisis has eaten into the fabric of this country and contributed to the division we are experiencing.
pcm: Di farmer-herders crisis wey don kontinu to dey apun don chop enter di fabric of dis nation and e follow join di division wey we dey experience.

en: As a matter of fact, ranching is where the solution to this problem lies because for every well-meaning Nigerian, RUGA, which stands for rural grazing area, has been with us since 1946, but it has been dormant.
pcm: As matter of fact, ranching na di solution for dis problem bikos for evri well meaning Nigerian, RUGA, wey stand for rural grazing area, don dey wit us since 1946, but e be don dey dormant.

en: In the 21st century, the best way to float production in the livestock system is to have farms or ranches for full commercial production.
pcm: For inside 21st century, di best way to take float production for di livestock system na to get farm or ranches for full commercial production.

en: Open grazing and travelling kilometres is outdated in every strata of humanity today.
pcm: Open grazing and to dey travel kilometre don komot for date for inside evri strata of humanity today.

en: So, this is an opportunity for us to harness our potential in agriculture, which we have forgotten.
pcm: So dis one na opportunity for us to tap awa potential for inside agriculture, wey we don forget.

en: The RUGA template we should adopt is unique and peculiar.
pcm: Di RUGA template wey suppose adopt dey unique and peculiar.

en: There are states that cannot have RUGA or ranches, but they have the potential to benefit in a very big capacity, in terms of livestock production.
pcm: State dem dey wey no fit get RUGA or ranch dem, but dem get di potential o take benefit for big capacity, concerning livestock production.

en: The farmer needs to produce what the herder would use as raw material, just as the cow dung is manure for the farmer.
pcm: Di farmer need to produce wetin di herder go use as raw material, just as di cow dung be manure for di farmer.

en: The RUGA should not be forced on all the states, but each state can take advantage of it, based on its own peculiarity.
pcm: Make dem no force di RUGA on all state dem, but each state fit take advantage of am, base on im own peculiarity.

en: If the far northern states build ranches, I expect the southern or middle belt states that can't have RUGA to take advantage of it by putting up large scale fodder of pasture production farming, which will sweep most of our teeming youth out of the streets.
pcm: If di state dem wey dey for far north buld ranches, i expekt say make southern state wey fit get RUGA take advantage of am make dem put up large scale fodder of pasture production farming, wey go sweep plenty of awa teeming youth komot for di street dem.

en: This is an opportunity for governors and commissioners of agriculture to look at how we can harness these potentials.
pcm: Dis one na opportunity for governor dem and commissioner of agriculture dem to look inside how we fit tap dis potential dem.

en: RUGA should not be viewed as a programme that would cause division.
pcm: We no suppose see RUGA as program wey go kos division.

en: When the federal government mooted the idea of the national livestock programme, some states, especially in the South, kicked against it, saying it was a way of taking their lands for herders.
pcm: Wen di federal goment be moot di idea of national livestock program, some state, especially di south, say no to am, as dem tok say na way to take kolekt dem land give herders.

en: As an expert, can you throw more light on how this can be resolved?
pcm: As expert wey you be, you fit torchlight how dem fit resolve am?

en: The salesmen of the president could not sell the idea properly because, as a matter of fact, the issue of RUGA settlement is not about land grabbing.
pcm: Di pipo wey dey sell di president no fit sell di idea welwel bikos, as a matter of fact, di issue of RUGA setllement no be to take kolekt land.

en: You can't go to Adamawa to grab someone's land, even if they are mixed with Fulani.
pcm: You no fit go inside Adamawa to kolekt pesin land, even if dem don mix with Fulani.

en: It does not work like that.
pcm: E no dey work like dat.

en: You have to look at the peculiarity of each state to decide if a settlement can be established there or not.
pcm: You go at peculiarity wey each state get to take decide if you fit establish settlement or not.

en: So the president and his cabinet should look inward and at the peculiarity of each state.
pcm: So make di president and im cabinet look inward and inside di peculiarity of each state.

en: That is why today, despite being the main programme of the president, the issue has not been nipped in the bud.
pcm: Na why e be say today, despite na di main program of di president, dem neva still see am do.

en: This is because they were doing it as a holistic approach in the country.
pcm: Dis na bikos dem dey do am as say na di whole kontri.

en: There are lots of government farms that have been abandoned; this is an opportunity to use them.
pcm: Plenty goment farm dem dey wey dem don abbandon; dis na opportunity to take use dem.

en: Let us come together to renegotiate this project and you will see that people will adopt this roadmap.
pcm: Let us kom togeda to take negotiate dis project again and you go see say pipo go adopt di roadmap.

en: Let us have a policy that is workable for us all, with sincerity of purpose.
pcm: Make us make we get policy wey fit work for all of us, plus make di purpose dey sincere.

en: There should be a proper dialogue between states that are arable for this project, and this will harmonise the relationships we all share.
pcm: Make proper dialogue dey between state dem wey dey fit for dis project, and dis one go put harmony for di relationship wey we share.

en: There are fears that the traditional Fulani may find it difficult to be confined in ranches, how will that be attended to?It is not confinement.
pcm: Fear dem dey say e go difficult for di tradtional Fulani to stay inside ranch, how dem go attend to dat one? No be to stay inside ranch.

en: Just as the indigenous people in other parts of the country are repulsive to this because they have not been given a sense of belonging to the project, it is the same with some indigenous Fulani that cannot move because they have intermarried.
pcm: Just as indigenous pipo for oda part of di kontri dey reject dis bikos dem neva give dem sense of belonging to di project, na di same wit some indigenous Fulani wey no fit move bikos dem don internarry.

en: There are Fulani that are resident.
pcm: Fulani dey wey dey live for there.

en: For instance, in Adamawa, there are those who stay in a place and they can be differentiated from those who engage in seasonal movements.
pcm: For instance, inside Adamawa, some dey wey dey stay for one place, and dem fit show diffence for di ones wey dey do season movement dem.

en: So they can also adopt the system of being in a place if the proper orientation is given.
pcm: So dem also fit adopt di system of say make dem dey oneplace if dem give proper orientation to dem.

en: What I am trying to say is that we should look for ways to stop the upward and downward movement.
pcm: Wetin I dey try tok be say make we find way to take stop di upward and downward movement.

en: Nobody will dispute the fact that fattening is when you keep cattle in a place.
pcm: Nobody go dispute di fact say fattening na when you kip cattle for one place.

en: This concept is not to imprison the herder but to provide new opportunities.
pcm: Dis concept no be to imprison di herder but to provide new opportunity dem.

en: Zamfara is noted as one of the states piloting RUGA, and you are a key stakeholder in the project; what is the situation now?
pcm: Zamfara na one of di state dem wey dey pilot RUGA, and you be key stakeholder for di project; wetin be di solution now?

en: The project is a bargaining chip for peace so that the economy would thrive.
pcm: Di project na bargaining chip for peace, so make economy for thrive.

en: When we started work, we were told that before Governor Matawalle came into office, the rate of banditry made the state inaccessible, but he was able to broker peace.
pcm: When we be start work, dem tell us say before Governor Matawalle be enter office, di rate of bandits make di no dey accessible, but im dey able to bring peace.

en: This should not only be applicable to herders.
pcm: Dis one no suppose apply for herder dem alone.

en: How do we harness and build up our own farming communities?
pcm: How we go take harness and build awa own farming community dem?

en: What other essential amenities and infrastructure do we need to give our farming communities?
pcm: Which oda essential amenity and infrastructure dem we need to carry give awa farming community?

en: Is it very good rural roads that would bring all those grasses out?
pcm: Shey na very good rural road go bring all di grass dem make dem kom out.

en: Is it good canals that would take water further to where the streams can't go, or are boreholes at intervals to give good water, primary health care?
pcm: Shey na good canal dem wey go carry water reach wia di stream dem no reach, abi na borehole for interval to give good water, primary health care?

en: There are basic things that need to be provided.
pcm: Some kind basic thing dey wey dem need to provide.

en: But it is a right of the citizens and should not be a privilege.
pcm: But na right of di citizen and e no suppose be priviledge.

en: Specifically, what do you have in the Zamfara RUGA project?
pcm: Specifically, wetin you get inside di Zamfara RUGA project?

en: The RUGA model encompasses 23 items.
pcm: Di RUGA model get 23 item dem.

en: We have the road network, which is about 13.673 kilometres.
pcm: We get di road network, wey reach about 13.673 kilometres.

en: The ranch is in the Ranji Sakida Grazing Reserve in Maradun Local Government Area; and it is 2,218 hectares.
pcm: Di ranch dey for di Ranji Sakida Grazing Reserve inside Maradun Local Goment Area; and na 2,218 hectares.

en: The pilot phase started with about 100 hectares, but due to natural formations, it took about 300 hectares.
pcm: Di plot phase be start wit about 100 hectare dem, but due to natural formation, e take about 300 hectare dem.

en: That is for housing and other structures, but we expect it to take almost the entire place because of pasture production.
pcm: Dat one na for house and oda structure dem, but we expekt say make e take almost di whole place bikos of pasture production.

en: There are other reserves meant for similar projects, like Zumi Gidan Jaja with about 36,200 hectares and the Dantsado Kuyanbana forest of about 10,000 hectares.
pcm: Oda reserve dey wey dem do for similar project dem, like Zumi Gidan Jaja wey reach about 36,200 hectare dem and di Dantsado Kuyanbana forest of about 10,000 hectare dem.

en: On the pilot phase, the state government acquired a pivot sprinkler system, which has about 850 meters in diameter and radius of about 475.
pcm: On top di pilot phase, di state goment be buy one pivot sprinkle system, wey get about 850 meter for diameter and radius wey reach 475.

en: Apart from the roads, we have water reticulation, which serves about 27 kilometres.
pcm: Apart from di road dem, we get water reticulation, wey dey serve about 27 kilometre dem.

en: There is a water storage facility, four overhead and four surface tanks, each of which accommodates 250,000 litres, cumulatively giving you 2million litres.
pcm: Water storage facility dey, four overhead plus four surface tank, each of dem dey carry 250,000 litre, all togeda go give you 2million litre dem.

en: Then we have solar-powered industrial boreholes, with 8 attached to each one.
pcm: Den we get industrial borehole wey solar dey power, wey dem 8 to each one.

en: We have 10 hand-operated boreholes, which are already sunk.
pcm: We get 10 borehole wey dem don use hand sink.

en: As at December, the reticulation had gone to about 18 kilometres, out of 27.
pcm: As at December, di reticulation don almost reach 18 kilometres, for inside 27.

en: We also have health facilities, including a primary health care with a 30-bed capacity and theatres, outdoor patients department, a nursery for delivery, which is attached to the maternity.
pcm: We also get health facility dem, wey include one primary health care with 30-bed capacity and theartre dem, outdoor patient department, one nursery to take deliver, dem attach am to di maternity.

en: We are not expecting any case that is more than the capacity of the health care.
pcm: We no dey expekt case wey pass di capacity of di health care.

en: There is the veterinary clinic, which has the capacity to accommodate about 1,000 herds within its own confines.
pcm: Veterinary clinic dey, wey get capacity to accommodate reach 1,000 withing im own confines.

en: And it has its own theatre and isolation rooms, including 12 paddocks.
pcm: And e get im own thaetre and isolation room dem, e include 12 paddocks.

en: There are markets with open and closed stalls and abattoirs.
pcm: Market dem dey wit open and close stalls and abbattoir dem.

en: But in the context of a Fulani man, he does not kill his animal in his environment, so he takes it to a far place to slaughter, so the abattoir is located outside the ranch.
pcm: But for di context of Fulani man, he no dey kill im animal for im environment, so e go carry am go far to kill, so di abattoir dey outside di ranch.

en: The abattoir is going to be in Maradun town.
pcm: Na Maradun town di abattoir go dey.

en: We have 210 plots for herders, each measuring 2,475 square meters, and are divided into four.
pcm: We get 210 plot dem for herders, each measure reach 2,475 square meter, and dem divide to four.

en: Six hundred square meters is given for the living area so that the herder can build his hut the way he wants it.
pcm: Na six hundred square meter dem give for area wey dem go live make di herder fit build im hut di way he want am.

en: The other three are divided, fenced and demarcated, with each paddock having a gate.
pcm: Dem divide di three wey reamin, fence and denarcate dem, each paddock get gate.

en: We provided a squat system for them and a soak-away to each house.
pcm: We provide squat system for dem and soak-away for each house.

en: Out of the 210 allotted plots, there are five bedrooms for the Fulani or Hausa leaders.
pcm: For inside di 210  plot wey dey, five bedroom dem dey for Fulani or Hausa leader dem.

en: Three and two bedrooms are for ward heads.
pcm: Two bedroom dem dey for ward head dem.

en: There are religious facilities: an eid ground, a central mosque and outdoor spaces that can accommodate up to 1,000 persons.
pcm: Religion facility dem dey: one eid ground, one central mosques and space wey dey outdoor wey fit take reach 1,000 pipo dem.

en: There is also an Islamiyya attached to the mosque, as well as a school, so that they can have an opportunity of Islamic and western education.
pcm: Also one Islamiyya dey attached to di mosque, plus one school, so dem fit get opportunity of Islamic and western education.

en: There are other spaces left for future development.
pcm: Oda space dem dey for future development.

en: What are the economic benefits of the settlement in the future?
pcm: Wetin be di economic benefit of di settlement for future time?

en: We have phases one and two.
pcm: We get phase one and two.
